item.title: Canada to Hike Defense Spending to Hit NATO Target This Year
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney announced a large increase in defense spending to meet NATO’s target this fiscal year, and said it’s necessary in “a darker, more competitive world” where US dominance is receding as other great powers rise.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Louise Moon

media:content.media:description: Military exercises in Saguenay, Quebec.

item.title: LA Suburb Scraps Contract to House Immigration Detainees for ICE
item.description: The Los Angeles suburb of Glendale, California, canceled a longstanding contract to house federal immigration detainees at a local police department facility, citing rising public controversy over the arrangement.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Clanton

item.title: LA Set for Fourth Day of Unrest as Newsom Resists National Guard
item.description: Los Angeles is heading into a fourth day of unrest with California Governor Gavin Newsom vowing to sue to block the Trump administration’s deployment of National Guard troops in the city, escalating a standoff over immigration raids that sparked protests over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: Law enforcement clashes with demonstrators in the Compton neighborhood of Los Angeles on June 7. Photographer: Ringo Chiu/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Sheinbaum Vows to Protect Rights of Mexicans Detained in LA
item.description: Mexico’s President Claudia Sheinbaum condemned what she described as human rights violations during the detention of Mexican migrants in anti-deportation protests in Los Angeles, adding that her government has activated all available consular mechanisms to help protect them.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's president.

item.title: CEOs, Trump to Tout Child Investment Accounts in GOP Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to gather corporate leaders at the White House Monday to highlight a provision in his tax bill that would deposit $1,000 into an investment account for babies born in the next few years, officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A sculpture of former US President George Washington in the Rotunda of the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump's signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.

item.title: Cuomo Says ‘Socialist’ Tax Hike Will Cause NYC Wealth Exodus
item.description: Andrew Cuomo, the front-runner in New York’s Democratic mayoral primary, said raising taxes on the city’s wealthiest residents would cause an exodus to states like Florida and Texas.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: Andrew Cuomo at the June 4 mayoral debate

item.title: Italian Vote on Citizenship, Labor Law Fails in Boost for Meloni
item.description: Referendums to liberalize Italy’s naturalization rules and bolster workers’ rights failed to garner enough turnout, dashing opposition hopes that a strong showing could weaken the position of right-wing Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Giorgia Meloni Photographer: Ludovic Marin/Getty Images

item.title: Senator Shot in Head ‘Needs a Miracle’ as Colombia Reels
item.description: Last Thursday, presidential hopeful Miguel Uribe Turbay warned that Colombia was fast sinking back into its violent past. Two days later, a gunman shot him in the head during a rally.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bristow, Patricia Laya

media:content.media:description: A protest against violence the day after the attack on Uribe in Medellin, Colombia, on June 8. Photographer: Jaime Saldarriaga/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Start Prisoner Swap After Recriminations
item.description: Russia and Ukraine started a major prisoner exchange on Monday after days of wrangling cast doubt over the only concrete result of peace talks last week in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer

media:content.media:description: A firefighter extinguishes a fire at a civilian plant following attacks to Kharkiv, Ukraine, on June 7.

item.title: US, China Hold Trade Talks in London to Address Export Curbs
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China kicked off in London, with the US signaling a willingness to remove restrictions on some tech exports in exchange for assurances that China is easing limits on rare earth shipments.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Catherine Lucey

item.title: UN Atomic Watchdog Says Iran Uranium Buildup Can’t Be Tolerated
item.description: The United Nations nuclear watchdog said Iran’s rapidly increasing stockpile of uranium enriched to just below weapons grade cannot be allowed to continue without a firm international response.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

item.title: Israel Blocks Greta Thunberg’s Ship From Reaching Gaza, Group Says
item.description: Israel intercepted a humanitarian aid ship en route to Gaza that was carrying activists including Swedish climate advocate Greta Thunberg, and said it would send those on board back to their home nations.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Jon Herskovitz

media:content.media:description: The Freedom Flotilla Coalition releases a photo on June 9 it says shows their ship Madleen being intercepted by Israeli authorities as it traveled to to Gaza. Source: Freedom Flotilla Coalition

item.title: LA Clashes Escalate as Trump, Newsom Spar Over Troops
item.description: Tensions flared in Los Angeles on the third day of anti-deportation protests, as demonstrators clashed with law enforcement while President Donald Trump and California Governor Gavin Newsom exchanged blame over the unrest and responsibility for restoring order.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers and US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Police officers clash with demonstrators outside the Metropolitan Detention Center, MDC, in downtown Los Angeles, California on June 8, 2025. US President Donald Trump deployed 2,000 troops on June 7 to handle escalating protests against immigration enforcement raids in the Los Angeles area, a move the state's governor termed "purposefully inflammatory." Federal agents clashed with angry crowds in a Los Angeles suburb as protests stretched into a second night Saturday, shooting flash-bang grenades and shutting part of a freeway amid raids on undocumented migrants, reports said. (Photo by Frederic J. Brown / AFP) (Photo by FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP

item.title: London Infrastructure Set to Miss Out in Reeves Spending Plans
item.description: London is set to miss out on extra funding for new infrastructure projects in Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ spending review on Wednesday, provoking an eleventh-hour row between the Treasury and the capital’s mayor, Sadiq Khan.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan

item.title: Trump’s Leverage Wobbles as China Trade Talks Get Started
item.description: One argument made for President Donald Trump’s tariffs is that they give him leverage over other countries. But what happens when signs emerge that his leverage is a diminishing asset?
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: Chile-US Budget Contrast Pushes 30-Year Spread to Pre-Covid Lows
item.description: Chile’s presidential hopefuls all seem to agree on one thing; the need to tackle what by global standards is a very moderate fiscal deficit. That marks a contrast with the US, and it’s showing up in bond spreads.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Gonzalez

item.title: Starmer Reverses Cut to UK Winter Fuel Subsidy That Hurt Labour
item.description: Keir Starmer’s government said more than three-quarters of pensioners in England and Wales will receive cold weather fuel payments this winter, reversing the bulk of a cut to the benefit that many of his lawmakers blamed for the ruling Labour Party’s waning popularity.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Housing in London during winter.

item.title: African Ratings Company Plans to Launch in Third Quarter
item.description: The African Credit Rating Agency, a continental initiative to provide alternative assessments of repayment risks, plans to start operations by the end of September.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: A vendor hands a Ghana cedi banknote to a customer at the Makola market in Accra, Ghana, on Friday, May 10, 2024. Ghana's cedi has declined 14% this year, a slump beaten only by currencies that have been devalued, including the Egyptian pound and Nigerian naira.

item.title: America Cast Itself as the World’s Moral Leader. Not Anymore
item.description: Trump is declaring an end to a postwar precedent.
item.dc:creator: Brad Stone

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Chaos Threatens His Push for Rust Belt Revival
item.description: President Donald Trump’s signature trade policy is threatening to backfire by upending other top priorities: the revival of US manufacturing and the American Rust Belt.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette, Miranda Davis, Brooke Sutherland

media:content.media:description: A sign in support of Donald Trump in front of a junkyard in downtown Springfield, OH,

item.title: Everyone Is Buying Time in an Unstable World
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI, Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Ukrainian Drones Hit Russian Plant Involved in Missile Output
item.description: Ukraine said its drones hit a Russian research and production facility that supplies components for missiles, as Russia unleashed a fresh barrage of air attacks overnight.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Ukraine said its drones hit a Russian facility that supplies components for missiles including for the Iskander system.

item.title: Senate Republicans Plan to Release Major Revisions to Trump’s Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans intend to propose revised tax and health-care provisions to President Donald Trump’s $3 trillion signature economic package this week, shrugging off condemnations of the legislation by Elon Musk as they rush to enact it before July 4.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. US House Speaker Mike Johnson said he is fighting to maintain the new $40,000 cap on state and local deductions in the draft tax bill now before the Senate, where Republicans are seeking to enact a less generous break.

item.title: Chinese Aircraft Carrier Seen Operating Deeper Into Pacific
item.description: A Chinese aircraft carrier made one of its deepest forays into the Pacific Ocean over the weekend as Beijing continues to project its military power further from its shores.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: The aircraft carrier Liaoning

item.title: Japan Should Use Asia Trade Bloc in US Talks, Party Chief Says
item.description: Japan should take a bigger role in a regional free trade agreement and use its expansion as a bargaining tool in tariff negotiations with the US, the leader of the country’s largest opposition party said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Yoshihiko Noda

item.title: NATO’s Rutte Calls For ‘Quantum Leap’ in Defense Investment
item.description: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte said members of the military alliance need to deliver a “quantum leap” in their collective defense amid the ongoing threat from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, and Mark Rutte in London on June 9. Photographer: Andy Rain/EPA/Bloomberg

item.title: S. Korea’s Lee, Japan’s Ishiba Vow to Boost Ties in First Call
item.description: South Korea’s President Lee Jae-myung and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba held their first phone conversation and vowed to seek ways to deepen bilateral ties so both nations can respond together to future challenges.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: KAZUHIRO NOGI/AFP

item.title: US, China to Resume Trade Talks With Focus on Rare Earths
item.description: The US and China are set to resume trade negotiations in London on Monday in a bid to further defuse tensions over rare-earth minerals and advanced technology following a phone call between leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping last week.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Daniel Flatley

item.title: LA Mayor Bass Seeks Peace After Trump Calls in National Guard
item.description: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass called for peace as thousands of people demonstrating against immigration raids clashed with security forces for a third day.
item.dc:creator: Virginia Van Natta, Isabela Fleischmann

media:content.media:description: The National Guard, police and protesters stand off outside of a downtown jail in Los Angeles on June 8. Photographer: Spencer Platt/Getty Images

item.title: Starmer Calls on Nvidia’s Huang to Train Up Britons on AI
item.description: Keir Starmer will make an appearance alongside Nvidia Corp co-founder Jensen Huang on Monday, as the British prime minister puts technology and artificial intelligence at the heart of his government’s plan to boost economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Julian Harris

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer and Jensen Huang during London Tech Week on June 9. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
